channel.description: Recent content in javascript on draptik

item.title: Remotly measuring temperatures with a Raspberry Pi using radio frequency modules from Ciseco (Part 3: UI)
item.description: Part 1 describes how to setup the hardware, part 2 describes how to to record/persist the sensor information. In this post I’ll describe how to display the data. TL;DR Download and unzip the source code from https://github.

item.title: .NET backend providing REST
item.description: TL;DR My AngularJS demo app has a new backend implementation using .NET Web API. … Recap Our goals: server side: minimal working REST API providing GET dummy CRUD users client side (angular): communicate with server side Setup Creating a Web API project is straightforward: Just follow the instructions at

item.title: link collection #3
item.description: JavaScript stuff: Basics of NodeJS and ExpressJS: REST, Authentication, Sessions Another great tutorial on SPAs: Authentication in Single Page Applications If you’re in for using JavaScript for your complete stack, try MEAN: mean.

item.title: Node.js backend providing REST
item.description: TL;DR My AngularJS demo app has a new backend implementation using node.js. … After some reading I decided I’ll stick with node’s express module. OK. Here is a ‘minimal’ setup for a node.

item.title: AngularJS and CORS
item.description: TL;DR While splitting my AngularJS demo app into independent back- and frontend projects (running two different servers) I stumbled across cross domain issues during development. This post describes how to implement CORS on the server and/or client side of an application.

item.title: RESTful CRUD with AngularJS
item.description: This post will show how to perform typical CRUD (create, read, update and delete) operations in AngularJS when consuming a RESTful web service. A prerequisite for this demo is a working RESTful web service.

item.title: AngularJS example using a Java RESTful web service
item.description: AngularJS is the current MVV-Whatever JavaScript framework by Google. Among other things, it provides bidirectional data binding. Although I’m neither a Java nor a JavaScript expert, I choose the following scenario for my ‘Hello-World’ example:
